paragraphs.text:
%md
# 1. Option A: Load Names into Hive
We have some name lists from US Census 1990 and US Census 2000. We simply put them into Hive for easy access.

result.msg:
1. Option A: Load Names into Hive

We have some name lists from US Census 1990 and US Census 2000. We simply put them into Hive for easy access.

paragraphs.text:
%sql
create database if not exists training

result.msg: result

paragraphs.text:
%sql
create external table if not exists training.last_names(
    name string,
    rank int,
    count int,
    prop100k double,
    cum_prop100k double,
    pctwhite string,
    pctblack string,
    pctapi string,
    pctaian string,
    pct2prace string,
    pcthispanic string
)
ROW FORMAT DELIMITED
FIELDS TERMINATED BY ','
STORED AS TEXTFILE
location 's3://is24-data-dev-spark-training/data/names/last_all_c2000'

%sql
select * from training.last_names limit 10

%sql
create external table if not exists training.first_names_male(
    name string,
    prop double,
    cum_prop double,
    rank int
)
ROW FORMAT DELIMITED
FIELDS TERMINATED BY ','
STORED AS TEXTFILE
location 's3://is24-data-dev-spark-training/data/names/first_male_c1990'

%sql
select * from training.first_names_male limit 10

paragraphs.text:
%md
# 1. Option B: Load Data from Files

Probably the more realistic way to load data in this specific case is to read it directly as a CSV file. Moreover we specifically added a dependency at the beginning, so we can use spark-csv to load CSV data without much hassle.

result.msg:
1. Option B: Load Data from Files

Probably the more realistic way to load data in this specific case is to read it directly as a CSV file. Moreover we specifically added a dependency at the beginning, so we can use spark-csv to load CSV data without much hassle.

paragraphs.text:
import org.apache.spark.sql.types._

val lastNamesSchema = StructType(Array(
    StructField("name", StringType, true),
    StructField("rank", IntegerType, true),
    StructField("count", IntegerType, true),
    StructField("prop100k", DoubleType, true),
    StructField("cum_prop100k", DoubleType, true),
    StructField("pctwhite", StringType, true),
    StructField("pctblack", StringType, true),
    StructField("pctapi", StringType, true),
    StructField("pctaian", StringType, true),
    StructField("pct2prace", StringType, true),
    StructField("pcthispanic", StringType, true)
    ))
val lastNames = sqlContext.read
    .format("com.databricks.spark.csv") 
    .option("header", "true")  // Use first line of all files as header
    .option("inferSchema", "true") // Automatically infer data types
    .load("s3://is24-data-dev-spark-training/data/names/last_all_c2000")

result.msg:

val firstNamesSchema = StructType(Array(
    StructField("name", StringType, true),
    StructField("prop", DoubleType, true),
    StructField("cum_pro", DoubleType, true),
    StructField("rank", IntegerType, true)
    ))
val firstNamesMale = sqlContext.read
    .format("com.databricks.spark.csv") 
    .option("header", "false")
    .schema(firstNamesSchema)
    .load("s3://is24-data-dev-spark-training/data/names/first_male_c1990")
val firstNamesFemale = sqlContext.read
    .format("com.databricks.spark.csv") 
    .option("header", "false")
    .schema(firstNamesSchema)
    .load("s3://is24-data-dev-spark-training/data/names/first_female_c1990")

%md
# 2. Create Distribution for various Parameters

Now we need to have some nice random distributions for three different use cases:

* Number of CDKs per user
* Number of Sessions per user
* Number of CDKs used per session

We will use a lognormal distribution for that

result.msg:
2. Create Distribution for various Parameters

Now we need to have some nice random distributions for three different use cases:

  • Number of CDKs per user
  • Number of Sessions per user
  • Number of CDKs used per session

We will use a lognormal distribution for that

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Lognormal Distribution

The following definition provides us with a lognormal distribution.

result.msg:
Lognormal Distribution

The following definition provides us with a lognormal distribution.

paragraphs.text: val lognormal = sqlContext.udf.register("lognormal", (a:Double) => scala.math.exp(a*scala.util.Random.nextGaussian()) )

result.msg: lognormal: org.apache.spark.sql.UserDefinedFunction = UserDefinedFunction(<function1>,DoubleType,List(DoubleType))

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Number of Linking Keys per User

First let's create a random distribution which will be used for sampling the number of linking keys (or cross device key, CDKs) per user. A linking key could be an e-mail address, a user-id of a web-site, a phone number etc. Realistically you'll probably find hashed data for these values, but nontheless that would be good enough for our use case. We assume that a user has a couple of these IDs, normally maybe 10 - 20.

result.msg:
Number of Linking Keys per User

First let's create a random distribution which will be used for sampling the number of linking keys (or cross device key, CDKs) per user. A linking key could be an e-mail address, a user-id of a web-site, a phone number etc. Realistically you'll probably find hashed data for these values, but nontheless that would be good enough for our use case. We assume that a user has a couple of these IDs, normally maybe 10 - 20.

paragraphs.text:
sc.parallelize(1 to 100000, 100).toDF
    .select((lit(14.0)*lognormal(lit(0.3))) cast IntegerType  as "count")
    .select(when($"count" < lit(200),$"count") otherwise lit(200) as "count" )
    .groupBy($"count").count().toZeppelin()

%md
# Create Distribution for Number of Sessions

Each user will create multiple web browser sessions. Some users only have a few sessions, while other have more sessions. We assume that a typical user has around 40 sessions, but there are also more extreme users with more sessions (for example those users who always clear their cookies will generate much more sessions - but this won't be modelled very good here.)

result.msg:
Create Distribution for Number of Sessions

Each user will create multiple web browser sessions. Some users only have a few sessions, while other have more sessions. We assume that a typical user has around 40 sessions, but there are also more extreme users with more sessions (for example those users who always clear their cookies will generate much more sessions - but this won't be modelled very good here.)

paragraphs.text:
sc.parallelize(1 to 100000, 100).toDF
    .select((lit(50.0)*lognormal(lit(0.4))) cast IntegerType  as "count")
    .select(when($"count" < lit(2000),$"count") otherwise lit(2000) as "count" )
    .groupBy($"count").count().toZeppelin()

%md
# Create Distribution of Number of Linking Keys per Session

Now each user has around 40 linking keys - it would be too easy if he used all those keys in all his sessions. Therefore we assume that only very few of these keys will actually be used in each session, something like 1-4.

result.msg:
Create Distribution of Number of Linking Keys per Session

Now each user has around 40 linking keys - it would be too easy if he used all those keys in all his sessions. Therefore we assume that only very few of these keys will actually be used in each session, something like 1-4.

paragraphs.text:
sc.parallelize(1 to 100000, 100).toDF
    .select((lit(2.7)*lognormal(lit(0.3))) cast IntegerType  as "count")
    .select(when($"count" < lit(4),$"count") otherwise lit(4) as "count" )
    .groupBy($"count").count().toZeppelin()

%md
# 3. Create a Random Hash Generator

We will need lots of unique session IDs and cross device keys. We will create pseudo random hashes for that. In order to create predictable results, we use an explicit seed for random number generation. Otherwise we might get different results everytime when the RDD is evaluated. And this might happen any time out of our control, even multiple times within a single action. And that would be really bad!

result.msg:
3. Create a Random Hash Generator

We will need lots of unique session IDs and cross device keys. We will create pseudo random hashes for that. In order to create predictable results, we use an explicit seed for random number generation. Otherwise we might get different results everytime when the RDD is evaluated. And this might happen any time out of our control, even multiple times within a single action. And that would be really bad!

paragraphs.text: val random_hash = sqlContext.udf.register("random_hash", (seed:Long) => new scala.util.Random(seed).alphanumeric.take(32).mkString(""))

result.msg: random_hash: org.apache.spark.sql.UserDefinedFunction = UserDefinedFunction(<function1>,StringType,List(LongType))

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Test Hash Generator
We simple generate some data, and inspect the result. Hopefully we like it.

result.msg:
Test Hash Generator

We simple generate some data, and inspect the result. Hopefully we like it.

paragraphs.text:
val hashes = sc.parallelize(1 to 10000000, 100).toDF
    .select(random_hash($"_1") as "hash")
    .cache()
    
hashes.toZeppelin(10)

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Check Quality of Randomness

Since the hash values will serve us as unique IDs, they better should be unique. Let's check that.

1. Group hashes by hash value
2. Count number of entries per group
3. Count number of results with a count higher than 1

result.msg:
Check Quality of Randomness

Since the hash values will serve us as unique IDs, they better should be unique. Let's check that.

  1. Group hashes by hash value
  2. Count number of entries per group
  3. Count number of results with a count higher than 1

paragraphs.text: hashes.groupBy("hash").count().filter(col("count") > 1).count()

result.msg: res19: Long = 0

paragraphs.text:
%md
# 4. Create Random Name Generator

Just for convenience, we also want to have user names. This will help us checking the results. We create random user names by using some name lists from US Census 1990 and US Census 2000. We then combine random first names with random last names for generating names.

result.msg:
4. Create Random Name Generator

Just for convenience, we also want to have user names. This will help us checking the results. We create random user names by using some name lists from US Census 1990 and US Census 2000. We then combine random first names with random last names for generating names.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Load Names
Now we load names from previously registered Hive tables. We store the results in broadcast variables for later processing.

result.msg:
Load Names

Now we load names from previously registered Hive tables. We store the results in broadcast variables for later processing.

paragraphs.text:
// Load names from Hive tables - or comment out if using file data.
val lastNames = sqlContext.table("training.last_names")
val firstNamesMale = sqlContext.table("training.first_names_male")
val firstNamesFemale = sqlContext.table("training.first_names_female")

// Extract only the names from all data sets and put the result into broadcast variables which will simply hold an Array of names.
val lastNamesBc = sc.broadcast(lastNames.select("name").map(_.getString(0)).collect())
val firstNamesMaleBc = sc.broadcast(firstNamesMale.select("name").map(_.getString(0)).collect())
val firstNamesFemaleBc = sc.broadcast(firstNamesFemale.select("name").map(_.getString(0)).collect())

result.msg:
lastNames: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [name: string, rank: int, count: int, prop100k: double, cum_prop100k: double, pctwhite: double, pctblack: double, pctapi: double, pctaian: double, pct2prace: double, pcthispanic: double]
firstNamesMale: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [name: string, prop: double, cum_prop: double, rank: int]
firstNamesFemale: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [name: string, prop: double, cum_prop: double, rank: int]
lastNamesBc: org.apache.spark.broadcast.Broadcast[Array[String]] = Broadcast(2)
firstNamesMaleBc: org.apache.spark.broadcast.Broadcast[Array[String]] = Broadcast(5)
firstNamesFemaleBc: org.apache.spark.broadcast.Broadcast[Array[String]] = Broadcast(8)

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Create Random Names
Now we create random names from first names and last names. We could use a UNION of male and female first names. But since we have more female first names than male ones, this would result in skewed data with a significant overrepresentation of women. Not important, but we do care :) So we first roll a dice for selecting the gender, and then we randomly select a name from the appropriate list.

result.msg:
Create Random Names

Now we create random names from first names and last names. We could use a UNION of male and female first names. But since we have more female first names than male ones, this would result in skewed data with a significant overrepresentation of women. Not important, but we do care :) So we first roll a dice for selecting the gender, and then we randomly select a name from the appropriate list.

import org.apache.spark.sql.types._
randomFirstName: org.apache.spark.sql.UserDefinedFunction = UserDefinedFunction(<function1>,StringType,List(LongType))
randomLastName: org.apache.spark.sql.UserDefinedFunction = UserDefinedFunction(<function1>,StringType,List(LongType))

%md
# 5. Create Test Data

1. Create a list of users (create a list of names)
2. For every user, randomly create number of CDKs, number of Sessions
3. For every session, randomly create number of used CDKs and select CDKs from user CDKs
4. Store Data

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Check Uniqueness of Session IDs

Of course every session key should be unique. We test this - but our data might have the same session key multiple times per user with different CDKs.

Idea is to perform the following steps:
1. Select only name and session from the data
2. Make these tuples distinct
3. Count the number of occurances of each session. Eaach session should belong to exactly one user, so all sessions should be distinct.
4. Filter the result, such that only sessions with a count of higher than 1 are left. These are illegal sessions with multiple users
5. Count the number of such illegal sessions.

result.msg:
Check Uniqueness of Session IDs

Of course every session key should be unique. We test this - but our data might have the same session key multiple times per user with different CDKs.

Idea is to perform the following steps:

  1. Select only name and session from the data
  2. Make these tuples distinct
  3. Count the number of occurances of each session. Eaach session should belong to exactly one user, so all sessions should be distinct.
  4. Filter the result, such that only sessions with a count of higher than 1 are left. These are illegal sessions with multiple users
  5. Count the number of such illegal sessions.

paragraphs.text:
sessions.select($"name",$"session")
    .distinct()
    .groupBy($"session").count()
    .filter($"count">1)
    .count()

result.msg: res62: Long = 0

paragraphs.text: sessions.count()

%md
# Save Result

Now since we are happy with our session data, let's save it in a file. I would use Parquet, but maybe you want to use something else, like ORC or Avro. I do not recommend to use JSON, though.

result.msg:
Save Result

Now since we are happy with our session data, let's save it in a file. I would use Parquet, but maybe you want to use something else, like ORC or Avro. I do not recommend to use JSON, though.

paragraphs.text: sessions.write.mode("overwrite").parquet("data/sessions")

%md
# Cleanup Memory

In case we cached some DataFrames or RDDs, let's unpersist these RDDs to free up memory in Executors.

result.msg:
Cleanup Memory

In case we cached some DataFrames or RDDs, let's unpersist these RDDs to free up memory in Executors.

paragraphs.text: sc.getPersistentRDDs.foreach { entry => entry._2.unpersist() }
